fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A boundary type is a type that describes the witness of a partial element being ``extensible''. Given a partial element u : [\alpha ] \to A, the boundary type A[\alpha \to u] is the type of elements a : A that ``extend'' u. A term a : A[\alpha \to u] is a proof that a : A and u : A agree on \alpha . Any term u : A is a term of A[\alpha \to u] because u is equivalent with itself. Thus, the boundary type internalizes two judgments: \Gamma \vdash a : A and \Gamma , \alpha \vdash a \equiv u : A. Boundary types can be thought of as a \Sigma -type: \Sigma (a : A) ([\phi ] \to A \equiv u).

Generally, boundary types can describe

The typing rules for boundary types are as follows:
Cubical type theory is a constructive approach to homotopy type theory..
Partial elements are elements of a type that are defined on the extent of a cofibration formula. Partial elements are used in cubical type theory to describe partially specified n-dimensional cubes.
I use the notation [\alpha ] \rightarrow A for the type of partial elements of A defined on \alpha . Partial elements internalize the structure of the judgement \alpha \vdash a : A.
The typing rules for partial elements are as follows:

A boundary type is a type that describes the witness of a partial element being ``extensible''. Given a partial element u : [\alpha ] \to A, the boundary type A[\alpha \to u] is the type of elements a : A that ``extend'' u. A term a : A[\alpha \to u] is a proof that a : A and u : A agree on \alpha . Any term u : A is a term of A[\alpha \to u] because u is equivalent with itself. Thus, the boundary type internalizes two judgments: \Gamma \vdash a : A and \Gamma , \alpha \vdash a \equiv u : A. Boundary types can be thought of as a \Sigma -type: \Sigma (a : A) ([\phi ] \to A \equiv u).
